title: How is Iago the main character in 'Othello' by William Shakespeare? - Quora

response.answer_text: A friend was just explaining that to me some weeks ago. Othello can be seen as coming out of the tradition of revenge plays, and in a normal revenge play of Shakespeare’s time the fellow who takes revenge is the main character. He announces his plans, he confides in the audience as his plans proceed, and in the end he gets his revenge. In Othello, it’s Iago who does all that. Shakespeare turns the tradition on its head, though, by presenting Iago as a diabolical figure rather than as a noble one.

While in a revenge tragedy Iago would be the main character, Othello is a classical tragedy rather than a revenge tragedy. Hence, Othello is the protagonist, Iago the antagonist. Othello has the hamartia, and suffers the inevitable defeat.

It depends on how you define the “main character.” Some people define the main character as the one who instigates most of the action of the play. In “Othello,” Iago instigates most of the action. Othello reacts to Iago’s actions.

A lot of Characters in Shakespeare can follow the alternate antagonist/protagonist role, Caesar and Brutus, Macbeth and Macduff for example. Macbeth goes crazy and murders the king and his best friend, while Macduff leads an army to stop him. Even in other literature, in Gone with the wind, Scarlett might be sometimes seen as the protagonist, but she is an antagonist and a terrible person.
